Bayview.tagline: Industrial grit meets waterfront renewal on the city's southeast shore.
Bayview.description: Once the backbone of SF's shipbuilding industry, Bayview is undergoing a slow renaissance with new parks along the bay, a growing arts scene, and deep roots in the city's Black community.

Bernal Heights.tagline: A hilltop village with the best skyline views and off-leash dog energy.
Bernal Heights.description: Bernal Heights feels like a small town dropped into a big city, with its beloved hilltop park, tight-knit community, and Cortland Avenue lined with indie shops and cafes.

Castro/Upper Market.tagline: The historic heart of LGBTQ+ culture and a neighborhood that never stops celebrating.
Castro/Upper Market.description: Anchored by the iconic Castro Theatre, this neighborhood wears its history proudly while sustaining a vibrant mix of nightlife, independent retail, and community activism.

Chinatown.tagline: The oldest Chinatown in North America, alive with lanterns, dim sum, and tradition.
Chinatown.description: Packed into a few steep blocks, SF's Chinatown is a sensory overload of herbalists, tea shops, and bustling produce markets that have served the community for over 170 years.

Crocker Amazon.tagline: Soccer fields, community gardens, and a quiet neighborhood that keeps it real.
Crocker Amazon.description: Centered around its massive park and playground complex, Crocker Amazon is a diverse, family-oriented neighborhood with strong Filipino and Latino roots and an easygoing pace.

Diamond Heights.tagline: Mid-century modern homes perched above the fog with panoramic city views.
Diamond Heights.description: A residential enclave developed in the 1960s, Diamond Heights offers dramatic elevation, easy access to Glen Canyon, and a quieter alternative to the bustling neighborhoods below.

Downtown/Civic Center.tagline: City Hall grandeur, world-class performing arts, and the pulse of SF politics.
Downtown/Civic Center.description: Home to the Beaux-Arts City Hall, War Memorial Opera House, and the Asian Art Museum, this area is the civic and cultural nerve center of San Francisco.

Excelsior.tagline: A proudly working-class neighborhood with some of the city's best hidden eats.
Excelsior.description: Tucked in the southern part of the city, Excelsior is known for its diverse mom-and-pop restaurants, McLaren Park's trails, and a community that fiercely resists displacement.

Financial District.tagline: Towers of commerce by day, surprisingly moody bar scene by night.
Financial District.description: The FiDi is SF's suit-and-tie district, home to the Transamerica Pyramid and Salesforce Tower, but its narrow streets and historic alleys hide speakeasies and century-old lunch counters.

Glen Park.tagline: A cozy BART-connected village tucked into a canyon with trails out the back door.
Glen Park.description: Glen Park combines small-town charm with big-city access, offering a beloved bookstore-cafe, excellent restaurants on Diamond Street, and immediate entry to Glen Canyon's wildlands.

Golden Gate Park.tagline: 1,000 acres of museums, bison, windmills, and the city's green lung.
Golden Gate Park.description: Stretching from the Haight to the ocean, Golden Gate Park holds the de Young Museum, California Academy of Sciences, Japanese Tea Garden, and countless hidden meadows and trails.

Haight Ashbury.tagline: Tie-dye legacy, Victorian architecture, and the eternal spirit of the Summer of Love.
Haight Ashbury.description: The Haight still channels its 1960s counterculture roots through vintage shops, record stores, and colorful Victorians, while attracting visitors from around the world to walk its storied blocks.

Inner Richmond.tagline: Fog-kissed avenues packed with the best Asian food outside of Asia.
Inner Richmond.description: Clement Street is the real deal for Burmese tea leaf salad, hand-pulled noodles, and dim sum, while the neighborhood's proximity to the Presidio and Golden Gate Park makes it a quiet gem.

Inner Sunset.tagline: UCSF students, craft breweries, and 9th Avenue's unassuming restaurant row.
Inner Sunset.description: Nestled between Golden Gate Park and the slopes of Mount Sutro, the Inner Sunset has a college-town feel with excellent food options, neighborhood bars, and easy access to nature.

Lakeshore.tagline: Lake Merced, SF State, and ocean breezes at the city's far southwest edge.
Lakeshore.description: Lakeshore is defined by the sprawling Lake Merced and its running trails, the Harding Park golf course, and a quiet residential character that feels far from downtown.

Marina.tagline: Joggers, brunch spots, and Golden Gate views from the waterfront green.
Marina.description: Built on landfill from the 1915 World's Fair, the Marina draws a young, active crowd with Chestnut Street shopping, the Palace of Fine Arts, and Crissy Field's bayside paths.

Mission.tagline: Murals, burritos, and the beating heart of SF's Latino culture.
Mission.description: Rapidly changing but still fiercely itself, the Mission blends world-class street art with some of the city's best food and nightlife, from Dolores Park picnics to Valencia Street bars.

Nob Hill.tagline: Cable cars, grand hotels, and old-money elegance on the city's most famous hill.
Nob Hill.description: Home to Grace Cathedral, the Fairmont, and the Mark Hopkins, Nob Hill is where San Francisco's Gilded Age wealth built its legacy in stone and marble.

Noe Valley.tagline: Stroller-friendly sidewalks, sunny weather, and 24th Street's boutique charm.
Noe Valley.description: Protected from fog by Twin Peaks, Noe Valley is a family-friendly neighborhood with a thriving small-business corridor, excellent coffee, and a farmers market on Saturdays.

North Beach.tagline: Beat poetry, red-sauce Italian, and espresso on Columbus Avenue.
North Beach.description: San Francisco's Little Italy is also the birthplace of the Beat Generation, where City Lights Bookstore, Vesuvio Cafe, and neighborhood trattorias coexist with Coit Tower looming above.

Ocean View.tagline: A quiet residential pocket with Balboa Park BART and community roots.
Ocean View.description: Ocean View is an affordable, multicultural neighborhood in the city's south, offering easy freeway access, proximity to City College, and a growing sense of local pride.

Outer Mission.tagline: Family taquerias, Balboa Park, and neighborhood life at an unhurried pace.
Outer Mission.description: Stretching along Mission Street's southern reach, the Outer Mission is a working-class neighborhood with deep Latino heritage, neighborhood bars, and access to McLaren Park.

Outer Richmond.tagline: Ocean Beach sunsets, Lands End trails, and the city's best kept food secrets.
Outer Richmond.description: The foggy Outer Richmond rewards explorers with stunning coastal hikes at Lands End, authentic Russian and Chinese restaurants on Geary, and a laid-back residential feel.

Outer Sunset.tagline: Surfers, sand dunes, and tapioca drinks at the edge of the Pacific.
Outer Sunset.description: The Outer Sunset is SF's beachy backyard, where surfers hit Ocean Beach, families gather at the zoo, and the N-Judah rumbles down Judah Street past eclectic small restaurants.

Pacific Heights.tagline: Billionaire's Row views, Fillmore Street shopping, and the city's most elegant homes.
Pacific Heights.description: Pacific Heights showcases San Francisco's most stunning residential architecture, with mansions overlooking the bay, upscale boutiques on Fillmore, and Lafayette Park's sunny lawns.

Parkside.tagline: Tree-lined blocks, Stern Grove concerts, and a neighborhood that flies under the radar.
Parkside.description: Parkside is a quiet, fog-belt residential area known for the free summer concert series at Stern Grove and easy access to Ocean Beach, Lake Merced, and the L-Taraval line.

Potrero Hill.tagline: Sunny slopes, design studios, and 18th Street's neighborhood feel.
Potrero Hill.description: Potrero Hill claims some of the city's best weather and views, with a walkable commercial strip on 18th Street, a thriving maker community, and proximity to the Dogpatch waterfront.

Presidio.tagline: A former military base turned national park at the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge.
Presidio.description: The Presidio offers 1,500 acres of forests, beaches, and historic buildings, plus world-class destinations like the Walt Disney Family Museum and Crissy Field's restored wetlands.

Presidio Heights.tagline: Quiet luxury between the Presidio forest and Sacramento Street's boutiques.
Presidio Heights.description: Presidio Heights is one of the city's most exclusive residential areas, with gorgeous homes, mature trees, and a refined shopping strip along Sacramento Street.

Russian Hill.tagline: Lombard Street curves, hidden staircases, and some of the steepest grades in town.
Russian Hill.description: Russian Hill is a walker's paradise of secret gardens, steep stairways, and sweeping bay views, anchored by the famously crooked Lombard Street and Hyde Street's cable car line.

Seacliff.tagline: Cliffside mansions, China Beach, and one of SF's most secluded enclaves.
Seacliff.description: Seacliff is a tiny, ultra-wealthy residential pocket perched above the Pacific, offering access to the hidden gem of China Beach and views straight to the Marin Headlands.

South of Market.tagline: Tech campuses, nightclubs, and the reinvention of SF's industrial south.
South of Market.description: SoMa is the city's most dynamic district, home to the SFMOMA, Oracle Park, countless tech offices, and a nightlife and arts scene that spans warehouse parties to gallery openings.

Treasure Island/YBI.tagline: A man-made island with skyline views and a wine-tasting scene emerging from the fog.
Treasure Island/YBI.description: Built for the 1939 World's Fair, Treasure Island is being transformed into a new neighborhood with stunning city panoramas, weekend flea markets, and a growing cluster of urban wineries.

Twin Peaks.tagline: The city's most iconic viewpoint, where fog rolls in like a slow-motion wave.
Twin Peaks.description: Twin Peaks offers a 360-degree panorama of the entire Bay Area from its windswept summit, making it the definitive spot for watching fog swallow the city at sunset.

Visitacion Valley.tagline: Community gardens, Leland Avenue, and a neighborhood building its own future.
Visitacion Valley.description: Visitacion Valley is a diverse, working-class neighborhood in the far south of the city, centered around Leland Avenue's small businesses and the community-driven Schlage Lock redevelopment.

West of Twin Peaks.tagline: Quiet streets, ocean views, and some of the city's foggiest microclimates.
West of Twin Peaks.description: West of Twin Peaks encompasses several sub-neighborhoods with winding streets, mid-century homes, and a suburban calm that belies its location within city limits.

Western Addition.tagline: Jazz legacy, Painted Ladies, and one of SF's most culturally layered neighborhoods.
Western Addition.description: The Western Addition holds Alamo Square's iconic Victorians, the Fillmore jazz corridor, and a complex history as the historic heart of San Francisco's Black community.
